questions.question: What are the materials that are attracted to a magnet called?
questions.explanation: The materials which are attracted towards a magnet are called magnetic materials, such as iron, nickel, and cobalt.

questions.question: Which of the following is a natural magnet mentioned in the text?
questions.explanation: Naturally occurring magnets, known as lodestones, were discovered in ancient times and used by sailors.

questions.question: How many poles does a magnet have?
questions.explanation: A magnet has two poles: the North pole and the South pole.

questions.question: What happens when like poles of two magnets are brought near each other?
options: They do not affect each other.
questions.explanation: The like poles of magnets, such as North-North or South-South, repel each other.

questions.question: Which of the following materials is non-magnetic?
questions.explanation: Materials that are not attracted towards a magnet, like wood, plastic, and rubber, are called non-magnetic materials.

questions.question: What is the name of the device used by travellers for finding directions?
questions.explanation: Travellers used a device known as a magnetic compass for finding directions. It has a magnetized needle that aligns with the Earth's north-south direction.

questions.question: In which direction does a freely suspended bar magnet always come to rest?
questions.explanation: A freely suspended magnet always rests along the north-south direction because our Earth itself behaves like a giant magnet.

questions.question: What happens when you bring the North pole of one magnet near the South pole of another?
questions.explanation: Unlike poles of two magnets, that is, the North pole of one magnet and the South pole of another magnet, attract each other.

questions.question: According to the activity with iron filings, where does a bar magnet have the strongest attraction?
questions.explanation: The experiment with iron filings shows that the maximum number of filings stick near the ends of the bar magnet, which are called its poles.

questions.question: Which of these is NOT a shape of an artificial magnet shown in the text?
questions.explanation: While the text mentions magnets can be of various shapes, the main examples shown are Bar, U-shaped, and Ring magnets. Spherical is shown in a later diagram but not in the initial shape introduction.

questions.question: Why did the sailors in Reshma's story need a magnetic compass?
options: To measure the depth of the sea.
To find directions when stars were not visible.
questions.explanation: Reshma's story created a situation where sailors were caught in a storm with an overcast sky, making stars invisible. A magnetic compass was the solution for finding directions.

questions.question: If you break a bar magnet in half, what will you get?
options: One piece with a North pole and one with a South pole.
Two smaller magnets, each with its own North and South pole.
One piece will be a magnet and the other will not.
questions.explanation: It is not possible to obtain a magnet with a single pole. If a magnet is broken, North and South poles always exist in pairs, even in the smallest piece.

questions.question: How can you make a sewing needle into a magnet, as described in Activity 4.4?
options: By heating it in a flame.
By repeatedly stroking it in one direction with a permanent magnet.
questions.explanation: Activity 4.4 describes magnetizing an iron needle by placing one pole of a bar magnet at one end and moving it along the length of the needle, repeating the process 30-40 times.

questions.question: Why does a freely suspended magnet align itself in the North-South direction?
options: Because the Earth itself behaves like a giant magnet.
Because of the moon's gravitational pull.
Because it is the most stable position aerodynamically.
questions.explanation: A freely suspended magnet rests along the north-south direction because the Earth acts like a giant magnet, with its own magnetic poles that interact with the magnet's poles.

questions.question: What is the key difference between a magnet and a regular piece of iron when freely suspended?
options: The magnet will align North-South, while the iron bar can rest in any direction.
The iron bar will spin continuously.
questions.explanation: Only magnets rest along the north-south direction when freely suspended. A piece of iron will not show this property and can rest along any direction.

questions.question: In the experiment with two magnets on pencils, why does one magnet move when the other is brought near it without touching?
options: Because of the magnetic force of attraction or repulsion.
questions.explanation: The movement is caused by the invisible magnetic force. Like poles repel, pushing the magnet on the pencils away, and unlike poles attract, pulling it closer.

questions.question: Activity 4.7 demonstrates that a magnetic field can pass through certain materials. Which of these materials was NOT tested?
questions.explanation: The experiment tested the effect of placing wood, cardboard, plastic, and glass between a magnet and a compass. An iron sheet, being a magnetic material, would interfere and was not tested.

questions.question: What was the ancient Indian navigation device 'matsya-yantra'?
options: A star chart made of fish bones.
A telescope shaped like a fish.
A magnetized fish-shaped iron piece in a vessel of oil.
questions.explanation: The text mentions the 'matsya-yantra' as an early form of compass used by Indians, consisting of a magnetised fish-shaped iron piece floated in oil to find direction.

questions.question: Which of these actions is warned against as it can weaken a magnet?
options: Using it to pick up paper clips.
questions.explanation: The 'Caution' section advises not to heat, drop, or hammer a magnet, as these actions can cause it to lose its magnetic properties.

questions.question: When you bring an iron bar near a magnet, what happens?
options: Only one end of the iron bar is attracted.
Both ends of the iron bar are attracted to either pole of the magnet.
questions.explanation: An unmagnetized magnetic material like an iron bar will be attracted to both the North and South poles of a magnet. Repulsion only occurs between two magnets.

questions.question: You are given two identical-looking bars. One is a magnet, and one is a piece of iron. How can you identify the magnet using only these two bars?
options: Bring an end of one bar to the middle of the other. If it attracts, it's the magnet.
Bring the ends of the bars towards each other. The one that can repel the other is the magnet.
Drop both; the one that breaks is the iron bar.
questions.explanation: Attraction can happen between a magnet and iron, or two magnets. However, repulsion only happens between two magnets (like poles). Therefore, if you find a point of repulsion between the two bars, you have identified both as magnets. The definitive test is repulsion.

questions.question: A bar magnet is rolled in a pile of iron U-clips. Where would you expect the LEAST number of clips to stick?
options: Equally at all points A, B, and C.
questions.explanation: The magnetic force is strongest at the poles (ends) and weakest in the middle of a bar magnet. Therefore, the fewest clips would stick to the middle section.

questions.question: A mechanic's steel screws keep falling. Based on the chapter, what is the best way to modify his screwdriver to solve this problem?
options: Attach a piece of rubber to the handle.
Stroke the screwdriver's tip with a strong magnet to magnetize it.
Heat the tip of the screwdriver.
questions.explanation: By turning the steel screwdriver into a temporary magnet (by stroking it with a permanent magnet), it will attract and hold the steel screws, making them easier to handle.

questions.question: The North pole of a magnetic compass needle points towards the geographic North. What does this imply about the Earth's magnetic pole located near the geographic North Pole?
options: It is a magnetic North pole.
It is a magnetic South pole.
questions.explanation: Since unlike poles attract, the North-seeking pole of a compass needle is attracted to the Earth's magnetic pole in the north. This means the Earth's magnetic pole in the geographic north is actually a magnetic South pole.

questions.question: In Figure 4.16, ring magnet X 'floats' above ring magnet Y. Why does this happen?
options: Magnet X is lighter than air.
There is a cushion of air trapped between them.
The like poles of magnet X and magnet Y are facing each other, causing repulsion.
The magnets are stuck to the wooden rod.
questions.explanation: The magnet X is held up by the force of magnetic repulsion. This occurs because the pole on the bottom of magnet X is the same as the pole on the top of magnet Y (e.g., North facing North).

questions.question: To make the floating magnet X in Fig. 4.16 touch magnet Y, what should you do without pushing them?
options: Place a piece of iron between them.
questions.explanation: Flipping magnet X over would place its unlike pole facing magnet Y. The force would change from repulsion to attraction, causing them to come into contact.

questions.question: In the arrangement in Fig. 4.17, if end 5 is a North pole, what must be the polarity of end 4?
questions.explanation: For the magnets to stick together as shown, unlike poles must be touching. The magnet with end 5 (North) must have a South pole at its other end. Therefore, end 4, which is touching that South pole, must be a North pole. The other end of that middle magnet would be South.

questions.question: In the arrangement in Fig. 4.17, if end 5 is a North pole, what is the polarity of end 6?
questions.explanation: Following the logic: End 5 is N, so its other end is S. This attracts end 4, making end 4 an N pole. The other end of that middle magnet is S. This attracts the magnet with end 6, making its touching end an N pole. Therefore, the far end, end 6, must be a South pole.

questions.question: Why is 'repulsion' considered the surest test for magnetism, rather than 'attraction'?
options: Attraction can occur between a magnet and a non-magnetic material.
A magnet can attract a magnetic material (like iron), but it can only repel another magnet.
Attraction only works at very short distances.
questions.explanation: A magnet will attract any magnetic material (like an iron bar). However, it will only repel another magnet when their like poles are faced. Therefore, if you observe repulsion, you are certain that both objects are magnets.

questions.question: The text states that magnetic effect can act through non-magnetic materials. What observation from Activity 4.7 supports this conclusion?
options: The compass needle stopped moving completely.
The compass needle was still deflected by the magnet even with wood or plastic in between.
The wood and plastic became magnetized.
questions.explanation: The experiment showed that placing non-magnetic materials like wood, cardboard, or plastic between the magnet and the compass did not stop the magnet's force from deflecting the compass needle, proving the magnetic effect can pass through them.
